thread.title: Unlikely volunteers pitch in at the food shelf
thread.title_full: Unlikely volunteers pitch in at the food shelf - WCAX.COM Local Vermont News, Weather and Sports-

author: Keith McGilvery
title: Unlikely volunteers pitch in at the food shelf
text:
MONTPELIER, Vt. - The Montpelier Food Shelf serves up enough food to make tens of thousands of meals and now the longtime community partner is getting an unexpected boost in money, as well as out of state help to stick to its mission.
Volunteers at the Montpelier Food Pantry have been lovingly described as pitbulls.
"Yeah, I think that is pretty accurate," said Carole MacIntyre, a retired Montpelier teacher.
For decades many of the women have been handing out groceries to folks in need across the Capital City.
"We are kind of the front lines, we meet people we sign them up, we determine if they are eligible," said MacIntyre.
Things can be busy here in a shop that's serving up supplies to make nearly 72,000 meals a year and the team is getting some unexpected help from hundreds of miles away.
"Here we are in Vermont because we felt there was a need here," said Patricia Marshall.
She's part of a group from the First Church in Sandwich, Massachusetts volunteering at locations around central Vermont -- including the Food Pantry.
"I think that is incredible," said MacIntyre.
"I think that is wonderful, that they are willing to do that, that's a distance," said volunteer Corrine Sheridan.
People may think that in an affluent town like Sandwich, or even here in the city, that there are no needs, there are no needs for extra food at the end of the month, at the end of the week when they run out of food and money, but there is, there is a big need," said Marshall.
The Food Pantry's director says that need includes a demand for fresh produce.
In addition to the out-of-state help she's also celebrating a new $2,600 federal grant to promote fresh offerings at the site.
"This money help us to display our produce in a more appealing way, it will help us to find better ways to store our produce, so it stays looking good, we'll be able to put up signs so people know what is here,” said Kristen Andrew, Executive Director of Just Basics.
The regulars are thankful for the help but they know grant dollars and service visits will come and go. They want clients to know that the one thing that won't change is that they are always welcome.
"There used to be some of them would act embarrassed and I said ‘why?’ This is why we are here and we could all be in this position sometime, and when you are able to help, help,” said Sheridan.
The Food Pantry is part of a program called just basics that runs a variety of different efforts to make sure people in the region get the food they need.
